title: Mastering Leadership: Fear, Firing, and the Agent Mindset
description: Matt Mochary, executive coach to CEOs of OpenAI, Coinbase, Reddit, and others, shares tactical frameworks for overcoming fear, mastering the art of firing, keeping teams small, and becoming someone's agent when letting them go.
summary: Matt discusses his coaching methodology including: why fear gives bad advice and how to recognize it, the importance of firing fast enough that you regret at least one, becoming someone's 'agent' when letting them go, separating decisions from implementation, and why smaller teams perform better than large ones.

key_themes.description: When leaders feel fear, their brains make exaggerated predictions - usually the opposite of reality
When letting someone go, become their agent - help them find their dream role with compassion
Every additional person creates geometric overhead - best companies stay remarkably small
Decide based on what's right for the customer, then implement with compassion for people involved

key_insights.quote: The biggest marker that I've seen between a botched layoff and a successful layoff is at the moment someone hears that they no longer have a job, did they hear it from their manager in a one-on-one? If that's when they heard it, it'll be okay. But if they heard it in an email, in a group chat... that is terrible.
key_insights.context: Opening wisdom about how to handle layoffs and firings
key_insights.insight: Layoffs must be delivered one-on-one from the manager - anything else feels dehumanizing

key_insights.quote: When someone's in fear, they're gripped. They can't see reality, their brain is making very exaggerated predictions. Whereas when someone is not in fear, and I'm not because it's not my situation, I am not gripped and therefore, my brain isn't making exaggerated predictions.
key_insights.context: Explaining why fear gives bad advice
key_insights.insight: Fear distorts reality - get perspective from someone not gripped by the same fear

key_insights.quote: You think you're going to lose their trust. I think you're going to gain their trust... Every single time that's happened, the board members have said, 'This is fantastic. I love this honesty. Thank you so much.'
key_insights.context: Advising CEOs to be transparent with boards about problems
key_insights.insight: Transparency about problems builds trust with boards, not destroys it

key_insights.quote: I don't mean physical danger, I mean things that we perceive to be danger to our egos.
key_insights.context: Clarifying what kind of fear to challenge
key_insights.insight: Challenge ego-based fears, not physical danger - check with others who aren't gripped

key_insights.quote: Finally she said, 'I perceive you to be in anger.' So it's an I statement and it's simply what she's perceiving. There's no judgment. That was able to punch through my anger.
key_insights.context: Learning how his wife gives feedback about anger
key_insights.insight: Use 'I perceive you to be in [emotion]' - it's non-judgmental and breaks through defensiveness

key_insights.quote: Anger is not a base emotion. Anger is actually a cover. It's a cover for when we feel pain, and so our brain doesn't want to feel the pain, so instead it externalizes it.
key_insights.insight: Anger masks pain - allow yourself to feel the pain rather than pushing it onto others

key_insights.quote: Have you ever let someone go and regretted it? ... Well, then you don't know what the bar is because the bar of where you should be letting people go is here, and the bar that you've let people go is here.
key_insights.insight: If you haven't fired someone you regretted firing, you're not firing fast enough

key_insights.quote: When I let someone go, I try to do it with a massive amount of compassion... I become their agent and I say, 'I want to help you discover what it is that your ideal role is, and I want to help you create it or land it.'
key_insights.context: Describing the agent mindset for firing
key_insights.insight: Become someone's agent when firing them - help them find their dream job with compassion

key_insights.quote: The litmus for me is that everybody I've let go, I believe anyway, that I continue to be friends with. That shows me that the process by which I let people go is a humane one.
key_insights.insight: If you remain friends with people you've fired, your firing process is humane

key_insights.quote: With fewer people in the organization, things work better. That's the big realization that most people never discover... every additional human you have in your organization causes extra overhead and geometrically so.
key_insights.context: Realizing smaller teams are better after letting someone go
key_insights.insight: Smaller teams work better - each additional person creates geometric overhead

key_insights.quote: Really the ideal is just to keep the team super small. That's what WhatsApp did, that's what Instagram did, that's what Linear is doing right now. That's what Notion has been doing for a while. Those, to me, are the real success stories.
key_insights.context: Examples of companies that stayed small
key_insights.insight: The most successful companies (WhatsApp, Instagram, Linear, Notion) stay remarkably small

key_insights.quote: She separates the decision from the implementation, meaning she thinks about who is the stakeholder here that I'm solving for? And almost always in a company, you're solving for the customer. So, what would the customer want to see happen? That's the decision.
key_insights.context: Framework from Wei Deng at Clipboard Health
key_insights.insight: Separate decision (what's right for customer) from implementation (how to do it humanely)
